hot.title: What it's like to drive the Tesla Model X
hot.author: Nick Jaynes

content.plain:
A few hours before Elon Musk took the stage and unveiled the Model X to the world, Tesla had invited a small group of journalists out to its Fremont, California headquarters to not only study the car up-close but also drive it.

Given fewer than 10 minutes of one-on-one time with the car, there wasn't a lot of time to snap detailed pictures, make a video and drive the car around the prescribed loop laid out on the back parking lots of the company's HQ.

See also: Tesla Model X revealed: 250-mile range, Falcon Wing doors, Ludicrous mode

Faced with a choice between the three, I jumped behind the wheel and gingerly took the course. Before I took off, however, Jeffrey Brian "JB" Straubel, Tesla's chief technical officer jumped into the passenger seat. Watching the images depicted by radar parking sensors on the 17-inch touchscreen at my right knee, I carefully backed out of the tent in which the Model X was parked and made my way onto the circuit.

Eerily quiet

Cruising at an eerily quiet 25 mph, the first thing that struck me about piloting the all-electric SUV was its Panoramic Windshield. Even while sitting further back (I'm 6-foot-5-inches tall), the windshield still stretched over my head. 

It may seem like a headline-grabbing feature since it is unusual, but the Panoramic Windshield visually invites front passengers into the scenery and road ahead. Although I had the steering wheel firmly in both hands, looking out through the massive piece of glass--the largest ever fitted to a production vehicle-- I felt like I was floating down the road.

Neck-wrenching

Breaking my momentary serenity, Straubel told me to hammer the throttle, as we were riding in the $142,000 P90D (Performance 90-kilowatt-hour dual-motor) Founder model with Ludicrous mode engaged. Forgetting the immediacy and severity of all-electric torque, I punched the throttle, unleashing all 259 horsepower in the front and 503 horsepower in the rear, and quite literally wrenched my own head backward. I giggled a moment, as I reached back to grasp my mildly injured neck.

After going full throttle a few more times and briefly enjoying watching the world melt passed my periphery in the Panoramic Windshield, I turned onto the slalom course. Slowly pushing into the accelerator once again, I hurdled the Model X through several S-corners.

To my amazement, I found the car incredibly planted while also remaining supple, in terms of ride quality. In addition to the competent air suspension, the stability comes from the front and rear motors ability to independently apply positive and negative torque. While the SUV body stays planted, so does the driver's. The well-cushioned seats kept me in place without making me feel as if I were being wedged into a small sarcophagus, as is the unfortunate feeling of tight sport seats.

17 speakers

Leaving the slalom, I turned back onto the straightaway. Instead of flooring the accelerator again, Straubel suggested I turn up the Model X's 17-speaker sound system. Tesla's press packet describes the precisely-placed speakers as being able to create a concert hall inside the cabin. Often this sort of description is akin to shameless embellishment. In the case of the Model X, however, it's pretty spot on.

There was little road and powertrain noise to compete with and the speakers didn't have much to contend with in the cavernous and well-constructed cabin either. The result is a sound experience that immerses the occupants rather than abrades them.

Falcon Wing doors

Pulling into a parking lot Tesla set up to demonstrate the flexibility of the Falcon Wing Doors, I slowly guided the Model X between a minivan and a full-size SUV. Leaving only a few inches beyond the sideview mirrors on either side, I commanded the car to open the rear doors with the push of a button on the center touchscreen.

Requiring only 30 centimeters of space to open, the doors feature ultrasonic sensors embedded behind the sheetmetal -- the first of their kind capable of seeing through metal -- that avoid obstacles and alter the opening operation. The doors perfectly sensed the cars on either side and opened accordingly. When I was ready to go, I hit the button on the touchscreen and they came to a graceful close.

First impression

Although I only had a few minutes behind the wheel of the Tesla Model X, I can say I am wholly impressed. A lot of the concerns I had with the Model S, notably its lackluster interior, have been addressed in the Model X. As Tesla co-founder and CEO Elon Musk pointed out, the upstart EV automaker could have simply made a taller, bigger Model S and enjoyed similar adulation from the public.

Instead, they shot for the proverbial moon, over-engineering virtually everything. And that care and precision is palpable from behind the wheel of the car. 

Amusingly, a lot of what makes the Model X special are features that bean counters at more established automakers would have nixed in the early stages. That's what makes Tesla so distinctive in the industry: They dare to dream. And in turn, the cars it creates delight the rest of us. 

 Have something to add to this story? Share it in the comments.

hot.title: The self-driving car is ready for prime time, but you still can't have one
hot.author: Chris Taylor

content.plain:
MOUNTAIN VIEW, CALIFORNIA -- Google -- or as co-founder Sergey Brin put it, "Google, ah, sorry, I mean Alphabet" -- held a thoroughly fascinating event for a small gathering of press here at the Googleplex Tuesday. Brin and his team showed off the latest data from the company's formerly secretive self-driving car project. We got to take rides in two self-driving prototypes: the familiar small box above and a beautiful Lexus model. 

Everything we saw told us the Google car is astonishingly advanced, alert to all possible dangers with an insanely detailed awareness of its surroundings, and way better than you pathetic humans at driving in general. It will free up whole new vistas of time in your life, give you more energy when you get home, and give your elderly and disabled friends a whole new lease on mobility. 

Just one problem: Nobody at Google could tell us when we can get our hands on one, or how much it will cost, or even who is going to make it. They dodged repeated questions on the topic. "I hope we can tell you more in a few years' time," Brin said, before casually exiting the event in his own personal driverless car. 

See also: Get out of the driver's seat, human

This made the event fairly unusual in the annals of Silicon Valley for a company this size. Imagine Tim Cook unveiling the iPhone 6S to the world's media, then shrugging when asked when we could get one. Elon Musk might have had slightly less interest in the Tesla Model X launch Tuesday if he'd announced his Gigafactory wasn't making any of the cars, it just seemed like a neat idea to show it off. (Actually, that sounds like something the parody account Bored Elon Musk might say.) 

The presentation on driverless cars was extremely effective at pumping the buying temperature, as salespeople say. In video after video, we saw just how effective the car was at understanding everything going on around it, four or five car lengths in every direction. We saw how the car's triple-threat combination of cameras, radar and lasers builds up a far more detailed real-time map of the road than any pair of human eyes could manage. We saw how it can detect a cyclist's hand signals, a police siren, construction cones, the stop sign on the back of a school bus. 

A cyclist shot a red light at a four-way intersection; the Google car was the only one that correctly guessed its trajectory and stayed put at the light rather than moving off and swerving. A child ran out unexpectedly around a blind corner; the car stopped before it even got to the corner. A woman in an electric wheelchair randomly chased a turkey around the road with a broom; the car didn't know what the heck was happening, but stopped anyway. 

The Google team says it has assembled the auto equivalent of white-hat hackers to try to figure out how to confuse the car. They've tried jumping out of sidewalk Porta-Potties into the road; they've tried jumping out of the back of flatbed trucks. Nothing fazes this machine. 

Its brethren have driven a combined 1.2 million miles autonomously and are adding up to 15,000 extra miles of experience every week, all of which goes into each car's memory to help it figure out further confusing situations; the company just rolled out more testing in Austin. The car has has redundant backup brakes and a redundant backup computer. In the Lexus model, the driver can take back control of a regular steering wheel at the push of a button. (The Google-made model only has four buttons: stop, go, windows, temperature.) 

As Google pointed out, there are some 30,000 deaths on the road in the U.S. alone every year, the equivalent crashing a hundred 747 jets annually. 

So if this can make us significantly safer, why isn't this anywhere near being a product yet? 

Reporters were left scratching their heads. Was the company trying to whet our appetites for an announcement in 2017? Could this press-boosting event be part of a strategy in the ongoing negotiations between Google (sorry, Alphabet) and potential partners in the car industry? Or does Brin just think that a whole lot of reeducation is necessary before the mundane world will accept what his labs have to offer?

Personally, I'm leaning towards the latter. The Google X division that Brin runs has been burned by the public response to Google Glass. It seemed to them a perfectly reasonable piece of technology that would reduce our dangerous dependence on smartphones; the world saw the weirdos chosen as "Google Glass explorers" and denounced them as glassholes. 

It wouldn't be at all surprising if Google X was excessively cautious about its next product roll-out. Indeed, Brin got a taste of the potential angry pushback at the event, from an Australian reporter who waxed lyrical about the generations of men in his family and their connections to their cars. How dare Google take this away from them? 

Brin fielded that one calmly. "I definitely empathize," he said. "In America, people have intimate relationships with cars, too. I love the feeling of being out on the open road, but that's 1% of my experience. Mostly it's stop-and-go traffic, or hunting for parking ... there's a future for both of these worlds. But for a large percentage of day-to-day driving, people are going to prefer this."

    Insert Yakkety Sax here #Google #selfdrivingcar #hyperlapse A video posted by Chris Taylor (@futurechris) on Sep 29, 2015 at 12:26pm PDT
 

In general, worrying about a glasshole-like reaction to the driverless car is like fighting the next war on the basis of the last one. Stick Google Glass on someone's face and they're still going to be a little weirded out. Stick them in a driverless car and they get it almost immediately, right around the time the car actually stops all the way at a stop sign or slows down when there are tiny pedestrians at play in a residential neighborhood. 

The company is full of anecdotes about driverless car testers whose lives were changed by the vehicle. One woman suddenly started running in the evenings and cooking for her family with all the energy she had left over from not fighting traffic for two hours every day. A blind man was brought to tears by his newfound ability to pick up dry cleaning and hit the drive-thru at Taco Bell. 

One woman on the team talked about how thrilled a neighbor of hers was that the cars were driving through her area -- because, she said, it made all the other cars on the road behind it slow down and actually obey the speed limit. Ask any parent who has lost a child to an auto accident how much we need this. 

Once you understand the technology and its inherent safety, the driverless car practically sells itself. Some caution is warranted, of course. But if Google takes it slow and cautious, that's no help at all to the 30,000 people who are going to be killed this year by humans behind the wheel. 

 Have something to add to this story? Share it in the comments.

hot.excerpt: Google's driverless technology is astonishingly advanced. Why is it nowhere near car showrooms?

hot.title: Donald Trump's campaign bus can be yours for $15,000
hot.author: Kimberly Truong

content.plain:
One person's trash can be another's treasure -- or, in this case, someone else's party bus. 

Donald Trump's abandoned 40-foot blue campaign coach, emblazoned with "TRUMP" along with his slogan, "Make America Great," can now be yours for $15,000. 

See also: Carve your own Donald Trumpkin in time for Halloween

Steve Drake, the bus's owner, told the Des Moines Register that the Trump campaign had used it for months, but recently abandoned it due to a shift in strategy. Drake, who owns and rents out five party buses, says he is a Trump supporter and was approached by Tana Goertz, the former Apprentice contestant who works for the Trump campaign in Iowa.

Though Drake typically charges about $100 an hour to rent out a bus, the campaign worked out a longer term deal with him, and paid to customize their own bus. 

“The campaign originally was out with it every day of the month, out seeing people, soliciting for Donald,” he told the  Register. “What I’ve been told from them is that basically [they've] switched and they’re going to be dedicated to being on the phones for this next 30 to 60 days trying to help with [the causes].”

The bus was originally listed on Craigslist, but the post was taken down. "It was ruffling some feathers," Mark Gearhart, the bus's mechanic told the Register. 

Though he didn't specify whose feathers were ruffled, he said, “I’m sure you can use your imagination and think about who.” He did, however, confirm that the bus is still for sale. 

Prior to being abandoned, it traveled back and forth through the state -- Drake estimates that it's gone through more than half of Iowa's 99 counties. 

The price may seem a bit steep for a 1998 model that has seen two transmissions, but Gearhart has complete faith in the coach.

“It’s an old bus but it’ll get you there,” he said.

In any case, Drake is deftly timing the sale of the bus with Trump's political popularity. 

“I figured if I could sell it while it’s hot, while Donald’s hot, I would try to do that. If not, I’ll just keep it and use it.”

Have something to add to this story? Share it in the comments.

hot.excerpt: A Trump bus: $15,000. Making America Great: priceless.
